title: Leid Stories
content:
The Community’s Tired of Asking, “Who’s Policing the Police? <!--more--> Two recent cases highlight the longstanding separate-and-unequal treatment African Americans and Latinos experience at the conjoined hands of the law enforcement and criminal-justice systems.
In the Bronx, NY, a grand jury on Wednesday (Aug.
7) found no reason to re-instate charges against a plainclothes police officer who on Feb.
2, 2012 chased 18-year-old Ramarley Graham from the street into the bathroom of his home and shot him to death, believing the Graham was armed; he wasn’t.
On Tuesday (Aug.
6), 18-year-old Israel Hernandez-Llach was caught spray-painting graffiti on an abandoned McDonald’s in Miami Beach, Fla.
Friends of Hernandez-Llach said officers high-fived each other and were laughing after one of them stun-gunned him.
Within an hour he was dead.Federal authorities have said they will review both cases, but the community’s tired of asking: “Who’s policing the police?”
